questions.question: They ............................ to the manager's decisions.
questions.description: 'Objected' takes the preposition 'to' before an object. 'Oppose' does not take a preposition before an object.

questions.question: The family ............................ her new fiance.
questions.description: Approve takes the preposition 'of' before an object.

questions.question: We are ............................. the idea.
questions.description: Object takes the preposition 'to' before the object.

questions.question: In this state, parental ........................... is necessary before a seventeen-year old can obtain a driver's license.
I object ........................... this.
questions.description: Here the 'to' after 'object' is a preposition. When 'to' is used as a preposition, it is followed by an -ing form, not an infinitive.

questions.question: Mother ........................... cigar smoking.
questions.description: The verb 'object' needs the preposition 'to' before an object.

questions.question: The boy kept the dog despite his sister's ........................
Several of the speakers .......................... the project.
questions.description: 'Objected' takes the preposition 'to' before an object. 'Oppose' does not take a preposition before an object.

questions.question: Many people are ............................. to the idea.
questions.description: Oppose can have both passive and active uses. Object is not used like this.

questions.question: The senate ............................. the new housing bill.
questions.description: When approve means 'pass' it does not take a preposition before the object.

questions.question: The child did something his father did not .....................
questions.description: 'Approve of' means judge as good or think highly of.
